mainPage.title: History of Capitalism
mainPage.content:
The Evolution of the Economic System That Shaped the Modern World

Capitalism, characterized by private ownership of the means of production, free markets, and profit-driven enterprise, has developed over centuries into the dominant global economic system.

Why Study Capitalism's History?

Understanding capitalism's evolution helps us:

  • Contextualize Debates: Current economic arguments have historical roots
  • Recognize Patterns: Boom-bust cycles have repeated throughout history
  • Evaluate Alternatives: Compare capitalism with other systems that emerged in response
  • Anticipate Change: Economic systems evolve in response to technological and social changes

subpages.title: Origins and Mercantilism
subpages.content:
Pre-Capitalist Economies

Before capitalism, most economies were based on feudalism (land-based agrarian systems with lords and serfs) or guild-based craftsmanship in cities.

Mercantilism (16th-18th Century)

Mercantilism was a precursor to capitalism where:

  • Nations competed to accumulate gold and silver
  • Colonies provided raw materials and markets
  • Trade was heavily regulated by the state
  • The goal was a positive balance of trade

Key Developments

The rise of banking (Italian city-states), joint-stock companies (Dutch East India Company, 1602), and global trade networks laid the groundwork for capitalism.

Adam Smith's Breakthrough

Adam Smith's 'The Wealth of Nations' (1776) critiqued mercantilism and argued for free markets, the division of labor, and the 'invisible hand' guiding self-interest toward collective benefit.

subpages.title: Industrial Capitalism
subpages.content:
The Industrial Revolution (1760-1840)

Beginning in Britain, the Industrial Revolution transformed production:

  • Factory System: Replaced cottage industries and artisan production
  • Steam Power: Enabled mechanization of manufacturing
  • Urbanization: Workers moved from farms to industrial cities
  • Capital Accumulation: Factory owners amassed unprecedented wealth

Social Consequences

Early industrial capitalism brought both progress and misery: child labor, dangerous working conditions, 16-hour workdays, and urban poverty. These conditions sparked labor movements and calls for reform.

The Rise of Marx

Karl Marx (1818-1883) analyzed capitalism's contradictions in 'Das Kapital,' predicting that exploitation of workers would lead to revolution. His ideas inspired socialist and communist movements worldwide.

subpages.title: Financial and Global Capitalism
subpages.content:
The Gilded Age (1870-1900)

Industrialization created vast fortunes for 'robber barons' like Rockefeller, Carnegie, and Vanderbilt. This era saw:

  • Monopolies and trusts dominating industries
  • Extreme wealth inequality
  • Anti-trust legislation (Sherman Act, 1890)
  • Rise of investment banking

The Great Depression (1929-1939)

The stock market crash of 1929 revealed capitalism's instability. Mass unemployment, bank failures, and deflation led to:

  • Keynesian economics (government intervention to manage demand)
  • New Deal policies in the US
  • Rise of fascism as an alternative in Europe

Post-WWII Golden Age

The period 1945-1970 saw unprecedented growth, a strong middle class, and the welfare state in Western democracies. Bretton Woods established the dollar-based monetary system.

subpages.title: Neoliberalism and Today
subpages.content:
The Neoliberal Turn (1980s)

Reagan (US) and Thatcher (UK) championed neoliberalism:

  • Deregulation of markets
  • Privatization of state enterprises
  • Reduction of union power
  • Lower taxes on capital and high incomes
  • Globalization of production and finance

Financialization

The economy increasingly centered on financial markets. The 2008 Financial Crisis exposed risks of unregulated finance and led to massive bank bailouts.

21st Century Debates

Current challenges to capitalism include:

  • Inequality: Wealth concentration rivals the Gilded Age
  • Climate Change: Can profit-driven systems address environmental limits?
  • Automation: What happens when machines replace workers?
  • Alternative Models: Universal Basic Income, stakeholder capitalism, and degrowth movements
